awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Acquisition of subject-verb agreement and the role of developing numeracy--A behavioral and electrophysiological study
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this dissertation project is to deepen our understanding of how language acquisition is related to the development of other cognitive abilities. Children seem to learn their first language effortlessly and rapidly. By three years of age, most children appear to speak in fully grammatical sentences and are able to learn up to ten new words every day. How language acquisition happens continues to be one of the driving questions in language research and an important one for all fields related to early childhood development. Knowing how children acquire a first language is crucial for understanding how a second language is learned and therefore is important for understanding how to more quickly integrate immigrant children into English-language schools in the US. This knowledge will also allow us to improve our toolkits for helping children who are challenged by language delays or by language impairments associated with developmental disorders such as Specific Language Impairment, Down Syndrome, and Autism Spectrum Disorders. 

This project looks at the development of subject-verb agreement, which is the element of grammar that allows us to distinguish between "The sheep grazes" and "The sheep graze", for example. Research to date suggests that children can produce subject-verb agreement accurately before they comprehend it. This appears to be a paradox because it is generally assumed that children understand language structures before they begin to produce them in speech. This study will investigate how English-speaking preschoolers' brains process this grammatical feature, and how well children produce and comprehend it, to develop a model of the relationship between these abilities as they develop between the ages of 3 and 5 years. Children's number skills will also be measured to look at whether their conception of the number line influences how well they comprehend the singular-plural distinction of subject-verb agreement, which is marked on English regular verbs by "-s" or no "-s". This dissertation grant will support the first study to investigate this question with a comprehensive approach that takes into account neural processing, production and comprehension of the sentences, as well as cognitive maturational factors, including maturation of numeracy skills. The results of this study will help us to understand grammatical development in English-speaking children and validate an approach to research on child language development that can be extended to other languages in which the same apparent paradox has been observed, including, German, French, Spanish, and the Bantu language Xhosa.

por.por_cntn:
Previous research on child language development has presented a puzzle. One set of findings suggested that by three years of age, children have mastered basic language skills, such as agreement between the subject and verb. For example, three-to four-year-old children produce grammatical sentences, such as “the dog jumps” (“s” on the verb shows agreement with the singular subject). However, other studies found no behavioral evidence of sensitivity to agreement violations during comprehension tasks in this age group (for example, “the dog jump”, where “s” is absent). The goal of this dissertation study was to verify whether the different patterns in language production and comprehension is related to the task the child is asked to do, rather than to a lack or recognition that sentences like “the dog jump” or “the dogs jumps” are infelicitous. An additional question addressed here was whether children’s developing understanding of number concepts would predict comprehension of number agreement (singular versus plural). We hypothesized that more mature cognitive skills associated with the concept of number would correlate with behavioral and brain processes that showed mastery of subject-verb agreement during sentence comprehension.

We tested our hypotheses using behavioral measures of language and number comprehension, and with brain measures of processing of grammatical and ungrammatical sentences in a task where children listened to sentences. In the behavioral tasks, the children were asked to point to a correct picture that corresponded to the sentence (for example, the child pointed to which of two pictures, the first with one dog jumping and the second with three dogs jumping, corresponded to the sentence “the dog jumps”). In the number tasks, the children were asked to count serially (1-2-3-4) as high as they could, and to do a number estimation task in which they guessed the number of dots on a card.

We obtained data from 20, three- to five- year-old children and 14 adults as controls in these experiments. Preliminary analysis on the child behavioral data showed that most of the children who were close to five years of age had mastery of number concepts, whereas three-year-old children showed variability in number performance. In addition, the results replicate other studies of English subject-verb agreement, showing that three-year old children can produce the correct agreement marker, but that they do not perform well on the behavioral comprehension task. Preliminary results with the brain measures indicate a complex pattern with differences for marked versus unmarked violations.  For example, the P600 (posterior positivity) brain marker of grammatical violation was much larger for the zero-marked violation (“the dog jump_”), than the -s marked violation (“the dogs jumps”). This P600 finding to zero-marked violations suggested that the participants were aware of the violation and attempted to repair the structure (hence the P600) while constructing sentence meaning. It is also possible that the zero-marked violation is not processed as an overt violation because children hear sentences, such as “I saw the dog jump”.  In this case, the P600 indicates reevaluation of the sentence structure. An attenuated P600 response to overt -s violations might indicate that these violations were either easier to process, or that the participants stopped attempting to construct sentence meaning after encountering the violation. Further analysis is underway to determine whether brain measures and/or numeracy skills correlate with behavioral sentence comprehension. These findings will increase our theoretical understanding of variation in language acquisition in typically-developing children. The findings also have clinical implications because these methods can be extended to testing populations with developmental language disorders. This study also served to train doctoral, masters and undergraduate students, most of whom were women, on experimental methods in the language sciences.
